1 Inverse functions

1.1 Mapping

Let A\AlphaA and B\BetaB be two nonempty sets. If there exists such a rule fff that every element xxx in A\AlphaA is associated with one unique element yyy in B\BetaB under the rule fff, then fff is called a mapping from A\AlphaA to B\BetaB, which is denoted by
f:A→B,f:A \rightarrow B,f:A→B,
f:x→y=f(x),x∈A.f:x \rightarrow y = f(x), x \in A.f:x→y=f(x),x∈A.

Here yyy is called the image of x under the mapping fff, and xxx is called the inverse image of y under the mapping fff.
The set A\AlphaA is called the domain (or domain of definition) of the mapping fff, denoted by DfD_fDf​.
And the set composed of the image(i.e. y) points of all the elements in A is called the range of the mapping fff, denoted by RfR_fRf​ or f(A)f(A)f(A).

surjection: If every element yyy in B\BetaB is the image of some element of A
injection: If any two different elements of A\AlphaA are associated with two different image points.
bijection: one-to-one mapping, not only an injection, but also a surjection.
